title: Budget issues at fore in Teaneck school board debate
text:
Budget issues at fore in Teaneck school board debate October 20, 2015, 6:04 PM Last updated: Tuesday, October 20, 2015, 6:07 PM By MARY DIDUCH Buy this photo BERNADETTE MARCINIAK/STAFF PHOTOGRAPHER From left to right, Dr. David Gruber, Kathleen Muse, Sarah Rappoport , and Gervonn Romney-Rice, candidates for the Teaneck Board of Education, participate in a debate at Teaneck High School on Oct. 19, 2015. . 
TEANECK — Five school board candidates exchanged divergent views on how the district can better manage its budget and make the most of its limited resources at a forum on Monday night. 
The largely civil debate among three incumbents — Dr. David Gruber, Gervonn Romney-Rice and Sarah Rappoport — and their challengers, Victoria Fisher and Kathleen Muse, covered issues ranging from the importance of athletics and extracurricular activities to the use of technology in classrooms. But the underlying theme of the night was the district’s budget. 
The board this year approved an approximately $93 million budget – 4.25 percent higher than last year’s spending plan — after several heated meetings that resulted in more than $3.9 million in spending cuts, including the outsourcing of 38 special education classroom aides and 32 lunchroom aides. The trustees tapped into its reserve funds to prevent further cuts this year, and raised taxes by $239 for the average district resident, raising questions about how the district will meet its budgetary goals for the next school year while aiming to keep taxes down. 
Fisher and Muse called for the board to seek grant funding to free up money in the district’s general fund. 
“There’s money out there and we’re going to have to grab the brass rings,” said Muse, a grant writer who has experience as a teacher and school administrator. 
Romney-Rice, the board’s vice president this year, and Rappoport said they favor finding external grants. But they argued that grants don’t represent a long-term solution for the district’s financial woes. 
“The grant probably lasts two years and it isn’t going to let you add a whole new program ad infinitum when you’ve got to pay the staff and maintain the facilities,” Rappoport said. 
Rice said the board could continuously stretch its limited resources by finding more opportunities to share services with the township and lobbying the state for better funding formulas. 
“That is the challenge — limited revenue with lots of expenses,” Romney-Rice said. 
At several points during the debate, which was held at Teaneck High School and moderated by Minna Greenberg of the League of Women Voters, Gruber pointed to teacher salaries as a possible source of savings, saying that about 70 percent of the budget goes to salaries. He said he supports fair wages, but there are limits to what the district can afford. He said he would rather spend money to create a preschool program. 
“It’s about a resource-allocation decision,” Gruber said. 
The candidates are competing for three three-year terms on the nine-member board in the Nov. 3 election.
